Справка
Astral Axis is an android reference application to help high school students learn astronomy. The Planets section contains basic information about the planets of the Solar System, where you can read brief information about them, as well as consider their 3D models. The Theory section contains basic theoretical information on the astronomy course in high school. There is also a table with the translation of astronomical units of measurement. Please leave a review on the app in RuStore or on the GitHub site in Releases.

" One of the most important astronomical tasks, without which it is impossible to solve all other problems of astronomy, is determining the position of a celestial body on the celestial sphere. 

 In ancient times, people believed that all stars were located on the celestial sphere, which as a whole rotates around the Earth. This impression is due to the fact that, as a result of the immense distance of celestial bodies, the human eye is unable to assess the differences in distances to them, and they appear equally distant. With the development of scientific knowledge, such a view of the celestial sphere faded away. However, the geometry of the celestial sphere laid down in ancient times, through development and refinement, has taken on its modern form, which is used in astrometry. 

 The celestial sphere is an imaginary sphere of arbitrary radius, onto which objects visible in the sky are projected, with the observer assumed to be at its center (Fig. 1). 

 Distances on the celestial sphere can only be measured in angular units: degrees, minutes, seconds, or radians. For example, the angular diameters of the Moon and the Sun are approximately 30 minutes. 

 One of the main directions relative to which the position of a celestial body is determined is the vertical line. The vertical line, passing through the center of the celestial sphere, intersects it at the zenith Z and the nadir Z′. The zenith is directly above the observer. 

 The plane passing through the center of the celestial sphere and perpendicular to the vertical line intersects the celestial sphere along a great circle – the line of the mathematical (true) horizon. 

 The celestial pole is the point on the celestial sphere around which the apparent daily motion of the stars occurs due to the Earth's rotation around its axis. 

 The celestial axis (PP′) is the line around which the apparent rotation of the celestial sphere occurs. It intersects the celestial sphere at the north celestial pole P and the south celestial pole P′. The daily motion of celestial bodies appears as if the entire celestial sphere rotates as a whole around the celestial axis from east to west. This motion is apparent: it reflects the true motion – the Earth's rotation around its axis from west to east. 

 The celestial equator is a great circle of the celestial sphere, the plane of which passes through the center of the celestial sphere and is perpendicular to the celestial axis. The celestial equator intersects the horizon at the points of east E and west W. The celestial meridian is a great circle of the celestial sphere passing through the zenith and the celestial poles. The celestial meridian intersects the horizon at the points of north N and south S. 

 The angle between the celestial axis and the mathematical horizon is equal to the geographic latitude (φ) of the observation site. The great circle of the celestial sphere along which the apparent annual motion of the Sun occurs is called the ecliptic. The ecliptic intersects the equator at specific points: the vernal equinox (^) and the autumnal equinox (d)."
" Systems of celestial coordinates are used in astronomy to describe the position of celestial bodies in the sky or points on an imaginary celestial sphere. Several systems of celestial coordinates are used in astronomy, convenient for solving various scientific and practical problems. The known planes, circles, and points of the celestial sphere are used. 

 The systems of celestial coordinates differ from each other in the choice of the main plane and the origin of the coordinate system. Depending on the task at hand, it may be more convenient to use one system or another. The most commonly used are the horizontal and equatorial coordinate systems. 

 To construct a system of celestial coordinates, one should select a certain main plane passing through the observer and intersecting the celestial sphere along a great circle. Then, through the pole of this circle and the celestial body, another great circle is drawn, intersecting the first one, and as coordinates, the angular distance from the point of intersection to the celestial body and the angular distance from a certain point on the main circle to the same point of intersection are taken. In the horizontal coordinate system, the main plane is the plane of the horizon, and in the equatorial coordinate system, it is the plane of the celestial equator. 

 The horizontal coordinate system is a system of celestial coordinates in which the center is placed at the observer's location on the Earth's surface, and the main plane is the plane of the mathematical horizon. One of the coordinates is either the altitude of the celestial body h or its zenith distance z. The other coordinate is the azimuth A (Fig. 2). 

 Altitude (h) is one of the coordinates of a celestial body in the horizontal coordinate system; it is measured along the circle passing through the zenith and the celestial body and expressed as the length of the arc of this circle from the horizon to the celestial body. This coordinate is analogous to geographic latitude. Altitudes are measured in the range from 0 to +90° towards the zenith and from 0 to +90° towards the nadir."
